fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any bisimulation E between models M and N and any two worlds x,y with xEy, M,x \Vdash \varphi ~\text {iff}~N,y \Vdash \varphi ~\text {for all modal formulas $\varphi $.}
For every ordinal \alpha , there is a unique initial ordinal \beta such that \alpha \approx \beta .
Consider the subset B = {\mathopen {}\{\gamma \in \alpha {^{+}}\colon \gamma \approx \alpha \}\mathclose {}}. Note that this is a non-empty subset, so it has a minimum \beta .

Let \gamma \in \beta , then the inclusion \gamma \subseteq \beta yields \gamma \preceq \beta . It remains to rule out \gamma \approx \beta . Suppose that \gamma \approx \beta , then we have \gamma \approx \beta \approx \alpha . This means that \gamma \in B, so \beta \in \gamma , but this contradicts foundation since we would have \beta \in \gamma \in \beta in this case.

Suppose that \gamma is an initial ordinal such that \alpha \approx \gamma . By , there are three cases \gamma \in \beta , \alpha = \beta , and \beta \in \gamma . The first and the last cases can be ruled out since initiality implies \alpha \approx \gamma \prec \beta and \alpha \approx \beta \prec \gamma these respective cases.
Let A be a set of ordinals. Then \bigcup A is an ordinal.
Assuming AC, every surjection is a retraction.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let f\colon A\to B be a surjection. Consider the family F := {\mathopen {}\{f^{-1}(b)\colon b \in B\}\mathclose {}}. Note that this is a family of non-empty sets since f is a surjection. Then AC gives a choice function c\colon F\to \bigcup F. Note that \bigcup F = A. Then we define i\colon B\to A by i(b) := c(f^{-1}(b)). It is routine to verify that it is the required injection.

fr:title.text: Congruent functions induce functions on equivalence classes

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Congruent functions induce functions on equivalence classes

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \sim \colon X\nrightarrow X be an equivalence relation and f\colon X^{n}\to Y be a congruence on \sim . Then g := {\mathopen {}\{({\mathopen {}[x_{1}]\mathclose {}},\ldots ,{\mathopen {}[x_{n}]\mathclose {}},y) \in ({{X}_{/{\sim }}})^{n} \times Y\colon f(x_{1},\ldots ,x_{n}) = y\}\mathclose {}} is a function.

For any {\mathopen {}[x_{1}]\mathclose {}},\ldots ,{\mathopen {}[x_{n}]\mathclose {}} \in {{X}_{/{\sim }}}, there is some y \in Y such that f(x_{1},\ldots ,x_{n}) = y since f is a function. Thus, ({\mathopen {}[x_{1}]\mathclose {}},\ldots ,{\mathopen {}[x_{n}]\mathclose {}}, y) \in g.

Suppose that ({\mathopen {}[x_{1}]\mathclose {}},\ldots ,{\mathopen {}[x_{n}]\mathclose {}},y), ({\mathopen {}[x_{1}']\mathclose {}},\ldots ,{\mathopen {}[x_{n}']\mathclose {}},y') \in g where x_{i} \sim x_{i}'. Then since f is a congruence, y = y'.

Let \alpha be an ordinal. Then for any \beta \in \alpha
\beta = \mathsf {IS}_{\in }(\beta ).
\beta is an ordinal.

Let \gamma \in \beta . Transitivity in \alpha implies that \gamma \in \alpha . Thus, \gamma \in \mathsf {IS}_{\in }(\beta ). Conversely, assume that \gamma \in \mathsf {IS}_{\in }(\beta ), then \gamma \in \beta by definition. Thus, extensionality gives \beta = \mathsf {IS}_{\in }(\beta ).

Transitivity in \alpha implies that \beta \subseteq \alpha . Thus, (\beta ,\in ) is a well order. It remains to show that \beta is transitive. To this end, suppose that \delta \in \gamma \in \beta . Then since \beta = \mathsf {IS}_{\in }(\beta ), we have \delta \in \beta .
If \alpha is an ordinal, then so is \alpha {^{+}} := \alpha \cup {\mathopen {}\{\alpha \}\mathclose {}}.

Let N be an inductive set admitting the induction principle defined in natural number set. For each n \in N, we define s(n) := n \cup {\mathopen {}\{n\}\mathclose {}}. Then for any m,n \in N, if m \in n then s(m) \in s(n).
Fix m \in N. Consider P := {\mathopen {}\{n \in N\colon m \in n \Rightarrow s(m) \in s(n)\}\mathclose {}}. Note that \varnothing \in P vacuously.

Now let n \in P, i.e., m \in n \Rightarrow s(m) \in s(n). We need to show that s(n) \in P, i.e., m \in s(n) \Rightarrow s(m) \in s(s(n)). Suppose that m \in s(n) = n \cup {\mathopen {}\{n\}\mathclose {}}. By union, m \in n or m \in {\mathopen {}\{n\}\mathclose {}}. In the former case, we have s(m) \in s(n) \subseteq s(n) \cup {\mathopen {}\{s(n)\}\mathclose {}} = s(s(n)). In the latter case, we have m = n by . Then s(m) = s(n) \in s(n) \cup {\mathopen {}\{s(n)\}\mathclose {}} = s(s(n)).

fr:title.text: Covers in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Covers in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to B is a cover iff \mathcal {C} satisfies y\colon B|\top \vdash \exists x\colon A.\mkern 5muf(x) = y in its internal language.
Suppose that f is a cover. Let e = (b,a)\colon E\to B \times A be the interpretation of f(x) = y in \mathcal {C}. Note that a is an isomorphism since the following is also an equalizer diagram.
By , {\mathopen {}\llbracket y\colon B.\exists x\colon A.\mkern 5muf(x) = y\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the image of the following composite.
By assumption, fa = b. Thus, the image of b coincides with that of fa.
Since a is an isomorphism, it follows that the image of f is isomorphic to \mathsf {Img}(b). Thus, \mathsf {Img}(b) is an isomorphism.
Assume the converse. Then the identity morphism factors through \mathsf {Img}(b), i.e., \mathsf {Img}(b) is an isomorphism. Thus, it follows that f is a cover.

fr:title.text: Composite morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composite morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to C is the composite of g\colon A\to B and h\colon B\to C iff \mathcal {C} satisfies x\colon A|\top \vdash f(x) = h(g(x)) in its internal language.

Suppose that f = hg. Then {\mathopen {}\llbracket h(g(x))\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket h\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} \circ {\mathopen {}\llbracket g\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} \circ \mathsf {id}_{A} = hg and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket f\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} \circ \mathsf {id}_{A} = f. Thus, the equalizer of {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket h(g(x))\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the terminal object, and the result follows immediately.

Suppose the converse. Then the identity morphism \mathsf {id}_{A} equalizes {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket h(g(x))\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. Thus, it follows that f = hg.

fr:title.text: Monomorphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monomorphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to B is a monomorphism iff \mathcal {C} satisfies x,x'\colon A|f(x) = f(x') \vdash x = x' in its internal language.

Suppose that f is monic. Let e\colon E\rightarrowtail A \times A be the equalizer of {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f\pi _{1} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x')\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f\pi _{2}. Then it follows that f\pi _{1}e = f\pi _{2}e. Since f is monic, \pi _{1}e = \pi _{2}e. Then it follows that e factors through {\mathopen {}\llbracket x = x'\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}.
Assume the converse. Suppose that fu = fv for some parallel pair of morphisms u,v\colon C\rightrightarrows A. Then it follows that (u,v) factors through e.
Thus, u = \pi _{1}(u,v) = \pi _{1}ew and v = \pi _{2}(u,v) = \pi _{2}ew. By assumption, \pi _{1}e = \pi _{2}e so u = v.

fr:title.text: Identity morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity morphisms in the internal language of a category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to A is the identity morphism iff x\colon A|\top \vdash f(x) = x is satisfied in the internal language of \mathcal {C}.

Suppose that f is the identity morphism. Then by , {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is \mathsf {id}_{A} \circ {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. But the equalizer with itself is the terminal object. Thus, \top \leq {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x) = x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} in \mathsf {Sub}(A) as required.

Conversely, suppose that the terminal object of \mathsf {Sub}(A) (i.e., the identity morphism \mathsf {id}_{A}) factors through {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x) = x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. Then it follows that \mathsf {id}_{A} equalizes {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. Since {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = \mathsf {id}_{A} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket f\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f, it follows that f = \mathsf {id}_{A}.

Let T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} be a doctrine with those structures listed in . Additionally, assume that T satisfies Frobenius reciprocity. Then there is a doctrine T^{\flat }\colon \mathsf {Elts}(T)^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} indexed by the syntactic category of T such that T^{\flat } admits comprehension schema.
This proof is adopted from Errol Yuksel's proof. Any error should be attributed to me.

That is, T^{\flat } sends each formula-in-context \Gamma .\varphi to its downward closure ordered by entailment. By assumption, each T(\Gamma ) is cartesian. Thus, each slice {{T(\Gamma )}_{/{\varphi }}} is also cartesian by .
For each morphism f\colon \Gamma .\varphi \to \Delta .\psi , we define T^{\flat }(f) to be the following composite:

This composite admits a left adjoint \exists ^{\flat }_{f} defined as the composite of the top morphisms of the following diagram:

The left-hand side computes to \psi ' \wedge T(f){{\Sigma _{g}}_{/{\psi }}}(\chi ), while the right-hand side computes to {{\Sigma _{h}}_{/{g}}}(T(k)(\varphi ) \wedge T(h)(\psi ') \wedge T(k)(\chi )). This is isomorphic to \psi ' \wedge {{\Sigma _{h}}_{/{\psi '}}}(T(k)(\varphi ) \wedge T(k)(\chi )) by Frobenius reciprocity. T(k), as a right adjoint, commutes with pullbacks. Thus, the right-hand side is isomorphic to \psi ' \wedge {{\Sigma _{h}}_{/{\psi '}}}T(k)(\varphi \wedge \chi ). Further, since \chi \vdash \psi , this is isomorphic to \psi ' \wedge {{\Sigma _{h}}_{/{\psi '}}}T(k)(\chi ). Then, \exists ^{\flat }_{f} inherits the Beck-Chevalley condition from \Sigma _{f}.

Since T^{\flat } has all the structures listed in , it admits a naming functor. Let us define {\mathopen {}\{\Gamma .\varphi \colon \mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}\}\mathclose {}}\colon T^{\flat }(\Gamma .\varphi )\to {{\mathsf {Elts}(T)}_{/{\Gamma .\varphi }}} by

Let \gamma \colon \Delta .\chi \to \Gamma .\varphi and \psi \in T(\Gamma ) such that \psi \vdash \varphi . Then {\mathopen {}[\gamma ]\mathclose {}}_{\Gamma .\varphi } \leq \psi iff \exists _{\gamma }(\chi ) \leq \psi iff \chi \leq T^{\flat }(\gamma )(\psi ) iff \chi \leq T(\gamma )(\psi ). But there is a morphism \gamma \to {\mathopen {}\{\Gamma .\varphi \colon \psi \vdash \varphi \}\mathclose {}} iff \chi \leq T(\gamma )(\psi ). Thus,
Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category and R \in \mathsf {Sub}(A \times B) be a relation satisfying the following sequents:

fr:ul.fr:li: Functional: x\colon A, y\colon B, y'\colon B|R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y') \vdash y = y'

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then there is a unique morphism f\colon A\to B in \mathcal {C} such that x\colon A,y\colon B|R \dashv \vdash f(x) = y is satisfied.

Suppose that {\mathopen {}\llbracket R\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is (a, b)\colon R\to A \times B. Then R(x,y) and R(x,y') may be respectively interpreted (up to isomorphism) as (a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2}) and (a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1}), where \rho _{1} and \rho _{2} are the product projections out of R \times B.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Now, suppose that {\mathopen {}\llbracket R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y')\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is (up to isomorphism) either composite of the following square.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { width = 4cm, nw = {R(x,y) \wedge R(x,y')}, nw/style = pullback, ne = {R \times B}, sw = {R \times B}, se = {A \times B \times B}, north = {(\gamma ',\beta ')}, south = {(a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})}, west = {(\gamma ,\beta )}, east = {(a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})} }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first sequent demands that \gamma = \gamma ' and that \beta = \beta '. Suppose that au = av. Then (a\rho _{1},\rho _{2},b\rho _{1})(u,bv) = (au,bv,bu) = (a\rho _{1},b\rho _{1},\rho _{2})(v,bu). Thus, u = v.
Note that {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\colon A.\exists y\colon B.\mkern 5muR\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is the image of a. This is an isomorphism by the second sequent. Thus, a is a cover.

Since a is a monic cover, it is an isomorphism. Thus, we can define f := ba^{-1}. Note that (a,b) is an equalizer of f\pi _{1} and \pi _{2}. Thus, the required sequent is satisfied. Suppose that g\colon A\to B also satisfies the required sequent. Then (a,b) is an equalizer of g\pi _{1} and \pi _{2}. Since (\mathsf {id},f) factors through (a,b) via a^{-1}, g\pi _{1}(\mathsf {id},f) = \pi _{2}(\mathsf {id},f). Then it follows that f = g.

fr:title.text: Soundness of deduction system for regular categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Soundness of deduction system for regular categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The deduction system defined in is sound.

The first two structural rules are given by reflexivity and transitivity in each preorder \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ). The last structural rules is given by the action on morphisms of the functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(\Delta )\to \mathsf {Sub}(\Gamma ).
Every finite conjunction rule is given by the universal properties of terminal objects and binary products.

The first existential quantification rule is given by Frobenius reciprocity proven in . The second existential quantification rule is given by the transposition across the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f^{*}.

The first equality rule says the terminal object in \mathsf {Sub}(A) is contained in the equalizer of \mathsf {id}_{A} with itself. Since the equalizer of the identity morphism with itself is an isomorphism (i.e., a maximal subobject of A), the soundness of this rule follows.
For the second equality rule, consider the following pullbacks. The right square is the pullback of \varphi along s.

Since s and t are equalized by the morphism s = t \rightarrowtail \Gamma , the outer square of the following diagram commutes. Thus, the intersection s = t \wedge \varphi {\mathopen {}[s]\mathclose {}} is contained in \varphi {\mathopen {}[t]\mathclose {}}.
Let \mathcal {C} be a category with finite limits and T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} be a \mathcal {C}-indexed (pre-)lattice such that

fr:ul.fr:li: For each object X \in \mathcal {C}, the fiber T(X) is cartesian.
For each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, f^{*} admits a left adjoint \Sigma _{f}.
Each left adjoint \Sigma _{f} satisfies the Beck-Chevalley condition.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then we can define a naming functor {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{X}}}\to T(X) for each object X \in \mathcal {C}. Moreover, for each morphism f\colon X\to Y in \mathcal {C}, the following square commutes up to isomorphism.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For each object f\colon X\to Y in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{Y}}}, take {\mathopen {}[f]\mathclose {}}_{Y} := \Sigma _{f}(1). To extend this assignment to a functor, it suffices to show that whenever there is a morphism \alpha \colon f\to g in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{Y}}}, {\mathopen {}[f]\mathclose {}}_{Y} \leq {\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y} in T(Y).

To this end, note that \alpha ^{*}(1) \leq \alpha ^{*}g^{*}{\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y} in T(X) because the unit of the adjunction \Sigma _{g} \dashv g^{*} gives 1 \leq g^{*}{\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y}. Since \alpha ^{*}, as a right adjoint, preserves terminal objects and f^{*} \cong \alpha ^{*}g^{*} by the (pseudo)functoriality of T, we have 1 \leq f^{*}{\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y}. Then, the transpose along the adjunction \Sigma _{f} \dashv f^{*} yields {\mathopen {}[f]\mathclose {}}_{Y} \leq {\mathopen {}[g]\mathclose {}}_{Y}.

fr:title.text: Subobject doctrine of a regular category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobject doctrine of a regular category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category, then the subobject doctrine \mathsf {Sub}\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} has comprehension schema.

Each fiber \mathsf {Sub}(A) has finite limits inherited from \mathcal {C}. By , each f^{*} has the required left adjoint \exists _{f}. They satisfy the Beck-Chevalley condition because images commute with pullbacks in a regular category. Then by construction the naming functor {\mathopen {}[\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}]\mathclose {}}_{X}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{X}}}\to \mathsf {Sub}(X) is just \mathsf {Img}, which admits the inclusion functor as a right adjoint.
Let \mathcal {C} be a cartesian category. Then an object B is exponentiable iff B^{*}\colon \mathcal {C}\to {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} admits a right adjoint \Pi _{B}.
Note that pullbacks over the terminal object 1 are products. Thus, we may assume that B^{*} sends each object A \in \mathcal {C} to the first projection B \times A \to B.

Suppose that B^{*} admits a right adjoint \Pi _{B}. B \times (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}) can be expressed as \Sigma _{B}B^{*}, where \Sigma _{B} is constructed in . By , \Sigma _{B} is left adjoint to B^{*}. Thus, we may define (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}})^{B} := \Pi _{B}B^{*}.

Conversely, suppose that B is exponentiable. Let us use the notation (\mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}})^{\dag } to denote the exponential transpose. Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A in a Heyting category. Then the Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} exists. Moreover, for any morphism f\colon B\to A, f^{*}(A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) \cong f^{*}(A_{1}) \Rightarrow f^{*}(A_{2}) in \mathsf {Sub}(B).

And A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest such subobject by the universal property of right adjoint.

fr:title.text: Coherent categories have an initial object

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Coherent categories have an initial object

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a coherent category. Then \mathcal {C} has a strict initial object.

We claim that the domain 0 of the least subterminal object of \mathcal {C} is the initial object. First, by , the projection map \pi _{2}\colon A \times 0\to 0 is an isomorphism for any object A \in \mathcal {C}. Thus, the composite 0 \xrightarrow {\pi _{2}^{-1}} A \times 0 \xrightarrow {\pi _{1}} A gives a morphism from 0 to A, proving existence. It remains to show uniqueness.
Let a,b\colon 0\rightrightarrows A be a pair of morphisms. Form the equalizer of a and b.
Since the codomain of e is 0, e is an isomorphism. Thus, ae = be implies that a = b.

fr:title.text: Strictness of the least subterminal object in a coherent category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Strictness of the least subterminal object in a coherent category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a coherent category and 0 \rightarrowtail 1 be the initial object in \mathsf {Sub}(1). Then any morphism f\colon A\to 0 in \mathcal {C} is an isomorphism.

By definition, the pullback of the least subterminal object along the unique morphism \mathsf {!}_{A}\colon A\to 1 is the initial object q in \mathsf {Sub}(A). Suppose that there is a morphism f\colon A\to 0. Form the following diagram:
Since q is initial, sq = \mathsf {id}_{0_{A}} by uniqueness. Thus, the initial object of \mathsf {Sub}(A) is isomorphic to its terminal object, i.e., A does not have proper subobjects.

Similarly, the pullback of q along \pi _{1} is the initial object in \mathsf {Sub}(A \times A). Then s\pi _{1} corresponds to a morphism from the terminal object to the initial object in \mathsf {Sub}(A \times A).

Thus, A \times A does not have proper subobjects, so in particular, the diagonal map \Delta \colon A\rightarrowtail A \times A is an isomorphism. Since \Delta is the equalizer of \pi _{1} and \pi _{2}, this implies that \pi _{1} = \pi _{2}. Thus, for any parallel pair of morphisms a,b\colon B\rightrightarrows A with codomain A, we have

Thus, \mathsf {!}_{A} is monic. Then the morphism p means that the subterminal object \mathsf {!}_{A}q is contained in the least subterminal object of 1, so p is an isomorphism. Then, f, as the composite of two isomorphisms, is also an isomorphism.

Let \mathcal {C} be a category. The following conditions hold.
If fg is a cover, then so is f.
If \mathcal {C} has pullbacks, then covers are stable under composition.
If \mathcal {C} has finite limits and covers are stable under pullbacks, then for any cover f\colon A\to B, f \times f\colon A \times A\to D \times D is also a cover.
1. Suppose that fg\colon A\to C is a cover and that f = mn, where m is a monomorphism. Then since fg = mng, it follows immediately that m is an isomorphism.
2. Suppose that \mathcal {C} has pullbacks and that f\colon A\to B and g\colon B\to C are covers and that gf = mn, where m is a monomorphism. Then form the following pullback.
Since f is a cover, m' must be an isomorphism. Thus, g can be factored as mg'{m'}^{-1}. Since g is a cover, m must be an isomorphism.

3. Suppose that \mathcal {C} has finite limits and that covers are stable under pullback. Let f\colon A\to B be a cover. Note that f \times f = (f \times \mathsf {id}_{B})(\mathsf {id}_{A} \times f). Thus, by condition 2, it suffices to show that f \times \mathsf {id}_{B} and \mathsf {id}_{A} \times f are covers, but both morphisms are pullbacks against f and covers are stable under pullback by hypothesis.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category with images and equalizers. Then every morphism of \mathcal {C} can be factored as a cover followed by a monomorphism. Moreover, this factorization is unique up to isomorphism in the sense that if A \twoheadrightarrow C \rightarrowtail B and A \twoheadrightarrow C' \rightarrowtail B are both cover-mono factorizations of the same morphism, then C \cong C'.

By the construction of images, every morphism f\colon A\to B can be factored as \mathsf {Img}(f)\vartheta _{f}, where \vartheta is the unit of the image adjunction. \mathsf {Img}(f) is monic by construction and \vartheta _{f} is a cover by .

To show the second half of the lemma, it suffices to show that every cover-mono factorization of a morphism f is isomorphic to \mathsf {Img}(f)\vartheta _{f}. Let hg be a cover-mono factorization of f. Then by the universal property of adjunction, there is a morphism s in \mathsf {Sub}(B) such that s\vartheta _{f} = g. By the definition of \mathsf {Sub}(B), we also have hs = \mathsf {Img}(f). Then, it follows that s is monic.
Since g is extremal, s must be an isomorphism.
In a regular category, every cover is a coequalizer of the kernel pair of itself.

We show that f' and h form a cover-mono factorization of the cover f, so f' is an isomorphism. Suppose that f'a = f'b. We need to show that a = b. To this end, it suffices to show that g'a = g'b since f' and g' are jointly monic. Consider the joint pullback of a and b along h.

Uniqueness then follows from the fact that f is epic.

By the construction of \exists _{f}, this is equivalent to showing the following isomorphism. \mathsf {Img}(f \circ (A' \cap f^{*}(B'))) \cong \mathsf {Img}(f \circ A') \cap B'
Form the following diagram, where the front, left, and right faces are pullbacks.

By the pasting lemma, the back square is also a pullback. Then since covers are stable under pullback in a regular category, the north edge of the back square is also a cover. The diagonal of the right face is \mathsf {Img}(f \circ A') \cap B', which forms a cover-mono factorization of the composite f \circ (A' \cap f^{*}(B')). Thus, by uniqueness, \mathsf {Img}(f \circ (A' \cap f^{*}(B'))) \cong \mathsf {Img}(f \circ A') \cap B' as required.

Then it follows that gs\vartheta _{f} = gh = \vartheta _{f}, but uniqueness implies that gs = \mathsf {id}_{A'}. Thus, g is a monic split epimorphism, i.e., an isomorphism.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose that \mathcal {C} is a cartesian category with images that commute with pullbacks. Let f\colon A\to B be a morphism and g\colon B'\twoheadrightarrow B be a cover. Since isomorphisms are stable under pullback, f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(g)) is also an isomorphism. Thus, \mathsf {Img}(f^{*}(g)) is an isomorphism. Then since f^{*}(g) is the composite of two covers, it is itself a cover.

Then by the pasting lemma, the composite f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(g)) \circ \widehat {\vartheta _{g}} is isomorphic to f^{*}(g) in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}.
Thus, f^{*}(g) admits another cover-mono factorization.
Then by uniqueness, C \cong \underline {A'}. Thus, \mathsf {Img}(f^{*}(g)) \cong f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(g)).

fr:title.text: Equivalent condition for the existence of images

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalent condition for the existence of images

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a category with pullbacks. Then \mathcal {C} has images iff for each morphism f\colon A\to B, the pullback functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(B)\to \mathsf {Sub}(A) admits a left adjoint \exists _{f}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(A)\to \mathsf {Sub}(B).
By , the pullback functor f^{*}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}\to {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} admits \Sigma _{f}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}\to {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} as a left adjoint.

Let g\colon B'\rightarrowtail B be an arbitrary object in \mathsf {Sub}(B). We need to construct a functor \mathsf {Img}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}\to \mathsf {Sub}(B) so that each morphism f \to g in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} corresponds to a unique morphism \mathsf {Img}(f) \to g in \mathsf {Sub}(B).
Let f \to g be an arbitrary morphism in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}. Then this corresponds to a unique morphism \mathsf {id}_{A} \to f^{*}(g) as follows:

This then corresponds to a unique morphism \exists _{f}(\mathsf {id}_{A}) \to g under the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f^{*}. Thus, we define \mathsf {Img} by the assignment f \mapsto \exists _{f}(\mathsf {id}_{A}). This assignment can be trivially extended to a functor: since the category \mathsf {Sub}(B) is a preorder, every morphism f \to f' in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} has to be mapped to the unique morphism \mathsf {Img}(f) \to \mathsf {Img}(f') in \mathsf {Sub}(B). This morphism must exist. Indeed, it is the lifting of \mathsf {Img}(f) against \varepsilon _{\mathsf {Img}(f')} depicted in the following diagram.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzpicture}[diagram] \SpliceDiagramSquare { nw = A', nw/style = pullback, sw = A, ne = B', se = B, north = \varepsilon _{\mathsf {Img}(f')}, east = \mathsf {Img}(f'), east/style = {>->}, south = \mathsf {Img}(f), south/style = {>->}, } \draw [->,morphism,exists] (sw) to (ne); \end {tikzpicture}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can now extract the components of the unit and the counit from this correspondence.

html:td.fr:p: Let f\colon A\to B be an object in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}. The identity morphism \mathsf {id}\colon \mathsf {Img}(f)\to \mathsf {Img}(f) is, by definition, the identity morphism \mathsf {id}\colon \exists _{f}(\mathsf {id}_{A})\to \mathsf {Img}(f), which corresponds to the unit \eta _{\mathsf {id}_{A}}\colon \mathsf {id}_{A}\to f^{*}(\mathsf {Img}(f)) of the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f^{*}.

Then since \mathsf {Img}(f) is monic, \eta _{\mathsf {id}_{A}} corresponds to a unique morphism \varepsilon _{\mathsf {Img}(f)}\eta _{\mathsf {id}_{A}}\colon f\to \mathsf {Img}(f), where \varepsilon is the counit of the adjunction \Sigma _{f} \dashv f^{*}. This defines the component of \vartheta at f. This is precisely the lifting of f against \varepsilon _{\mathsf {Img}(f)}.

This morphism corresponds to a unique morphism \exists _{f}(\mathsf {id}_{A}) \to f under the adjunction \exists _{f} \dashv f^{*}, which we take as the component of \zeta at f.

A category \mathcal {C} is locally cartesian iff it has pullbacks.

If \mathcal {C} is locally cartesian, then {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} has products for any object A \in \mathcal {C}. But, products in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} are pullbacks over A. Thus, \mathcal {C} has pullbacks.

Conversely, assume that \mathcal {C} has pullbacks. Then since the forgetful functor \Sigma _{A}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}\to \mathcal {C} creates connected limits for any object A \in \mathcal {C}, the slice {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} has pullbacks. Moreover, \mathsf {id}_{A} is the terminal object in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}. Thus, {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} is cartesian.

fr:title.text: Slice comparison functor of a locally cartesian category admits a right adjoint

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Slice comparison functor of a locally cartesian category admits a right adjoint

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A category \mathcal {C} is locally cartesian iff for all morphisms f of \mathcal {C}, the functor \Sigma _{f} constructed in admits a right adjoint f^{*}. Moreover, f^{*} is (isomorphic to) the pullback functor.
By , locally cartesian categories are precisely those categories with pullbacks.
Suppose that \Sigma _{f} \dashv f^{*} for any f. We show that the following diagram

is a pullback, where \varepsilon _{g} is the counit of the adjunction. Note that since f \circ f^{*}(g) = \Sigma _{f}(f^{*}(g)) by construction, the component \varepsilon _{g} makes the diagram commute.
Let h'\colon C\to A and h\colon C\to B' be morphisms such that fh' = gh.
Note that h is a morphism h\colon \Sigma _{f}(h')\to g in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}. Thus, it corresponds to a unique morphism h^{\dag }\colon h'\to f^{*}(g) under the adjunction.

The transpose of h^{\dag } can be computed as \varepsilon _{g} \circ \Sigma _{f}(h^{\dag }). Since \Sigma _{f} is the identity on morphisms, we have (h^{\dag })^{\dag } = \varepsilon _{g} \circ \Sigma _{f}(h^{\dag }) = \varepsilon _{g} \circ h^{\dag } = h Thus, the top triangle also commutes.
Suppose that \mathcal {C} has pullbacks. Then we can take f^{*} to be the pullback functor. It remains to check that \Sigma _{f} \dashv f^{*}.
By construction, \varepsilon _{\Sigma _{f}}\eta = \mathsf {id}_{\Sigma _{f}}. Thus, it remains to verify the other triangle equality.

Let g \in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} be an object. We need to show that f^{*}(\varepsilon _{g})\eta _{f^{*}(g)} = \mathsf {id}_{f^{*}(g)}. Note that f^{*}(g)f^{*}(\varepsilon _{g})\eta _{f^{*}(g)} = f^{*}(g) by the construction of f^{*}. Moreover, we also have the following equation.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} \varepsilon _{g}f^{*}(\varepsilon _{g})\eta _{f^{*}(g)} &= \varepsilon _{g}\varepsilon _{f \circ f^{*}(g)}\eta _{f^{*}(g)} && \text {by the construction of } f^{*}\\ &= \varepsilon _{g}\mathsf {id} && \text {by the construction of } \eta \\ &= \varepsilon _{g} \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Thus, f^{*}(\varepsilon _{g})\eta _{f^{*}(g)} corresponds to the same cone over f and g as \mathsf {id}_{f^{*}(g)}. Then uniqueness implies that they are equal.

fr:title.text: Isomorphic subobjects have the same classifying morphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Isomorphic subobjects have the same classifying morphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let m\colon A'\rightarrowtail A and n\colon A''\rightarrowtail A be subobjects. Then m \cong n in \mathsf {Sub}(A) iff \chi _{m} = \chi _{n}.

fr:title.text: Monomorphisms in a category equipped with a subobject classifier are regular

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monomorphisms in a category equipped with a subobject classifier are regular

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a cartesian category equipped with a subobject classifier. Every monomorphism in \mathcal {C} is regular.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Note that the generic subobject \top \colon 1\rightarrowtail \Omega is a split monomorphism, so it is also a regular monomorphism. Explicitly, \top is the equalizer of \mathsf {id}_{\Omega } and \Omega \xrightarrow {\mathsf {!}_{\Omega }} 1 \xrightarrow {\top } \Omega .
Since every monomorphism in \mathcal {C} is a pullback against \top and regular monomorphisms are stable under pullback, it follows that every monomorphism in \mathcal {C} is regular.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be an arbitrary category and f\colon A\to B be a morphism. There is a faithful functor \Sigma _{f}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}\to {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} whose action on objects is the assignment g \mapsto fg.
Note that the category {{({{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}})}_{/{f}}} consists of the following data:
Thus, we may take \Sigma _{f} to be the forgetful functor {{({{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}})}_{/{f}}} \to {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}.
If \mathcal {C} has pullbacks then the assignment A \mapsto \mathsf {Sub}(A) can be extended to a pseudofunctor \mathsf {Sub}\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op} \to \mathsf {CAT}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
It suffices to specify an action on morphisms. Let f\colon A\to B be an arbitrary morphism. Since monomorphisms are stable under pullback, the pullback functor f^{*}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}\to {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} restricts to a functor f^{*}\colon \mathsf {Sub}(B)\to \mathsf {Sub}(A). Then pseudofunctoriality follows from the following facts:
Let f\colon A \to B, g\colon B \to C, and m\colon C' \rightarrowtail C be given. By the pasting lemma of pullbacks, the pullback f^{*}g^{*}(m) is also a pullback along gf. Thus, the universal property of pullbacks guarantees that (gf)^{*}(m) \cong f^{*}g^{*}(m) in \mathsf {Sub}(A).
The pullback against the identity is always an isomorphism. Thus, for any m\colon A' \rightarrowtail A, \mathsf {id}_{A}^{*}(m) \cong m in \mathsf {Sub}(A).

fr:title.text: Separated objects correspond to closed diagonal relations

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Separated objects correspond to closed diagonal relations

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An object A of a topos \mathcal {E} is separated iff the diagonal subobject \Delta \colon A \rightarrowtail A \times A is closed.

fr:title.text: Every equivalence relation in a topos is effective

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every equivalence relation in a topos is effective

fr:title.text: Subobjects of separated objects are separated

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobjects of separated objects are separated

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a separated object in a topos \mathcal {E}. Any subobject m\colon A' \rightarrowtail A is separated.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let m'\colon B' \rightarrowtail B be a dense subobject and f\colon B' \to A' be any morphism. If f = gm' = hm' then mf = mgm' = mhm'. First, mg = mh because A is separated. Then it follows that g = h because m is a monomorphism.
